issues.title: why static routing does not suffice (and NASR comes out)
issues.author: liuchunchi
issues.body:
People from previous side meetings asked (and was put in the Q&As) that why static routing cannot do the work and NASR is needed. I think there are two reasons

1. When we are using SRv6 and orchestrate a security-qualifying path, it **is** essentially static routing. 
2. Given 1, we need POT to inspect forwarding security. Current SRv6 does not guanrantee that functionality. At least no **cryptographic verifiable transit proofs**.  
3. There are no verifiable proofs **proving the security properties** of the provided path/connectivity service. 

What do you think? Should we add to draft?

comments.author: dr2lopez
comments.body:
Hi,

Indeed. Any orchestrated path is essentially a static route, only that it is programmable…

And I agree the key point is on the verifications you can make, whether the path has been programmed (orchestrated) or the result of a human decision.
